title: What is the significance of sound and language in ancient Indian civilization?
first_phrase: This text explores the significance of sound in ancient Indian culture, particularly in the form of mantra and how these words were believed to have power and effect on the world around them. The author discusses the idea that these sounds were seen and treated as sacred, and were used in ritual sacrifices to invoke specific effects. The text also touches on the importance of language and its regulation in Indian civilization, with a focus on the Veda and the concept of Brahman. The final 200 tokens delve into the idea of logic and rationalism in Indian culture, particularly in contrast to the prominence of sound and language. It acknowledges the presence of materialists, Buddhists, and Jains who prioritize thoughts and actions over words, and how this contrasts with the broader cultural emphasis on sound and word power.

La costituzione ad assoluto di Veic, la parola, e soprat- tutto del Brahman, la formula rituale, testimonia il presti- gio che l'India attribuisce al verbo in quanto chiave del sapere e del potere. Gli ambienti che si sottraggono a questo prestigio sono rari, e soprattutto sparsi: i negatori del Veda (Vedanindaka), razionalisti o sofisti; i materialisti, i huddhisti e gli Jaina, indifferenti rispetto alla tradizione vedi- ca e preoccupati molto piú di pensieri e di atti che non di parole. last_phrase: In conclusion, the Indian civilization has attributed great importance to the power of words, considering it a key element in knowledge and power, and this belief has been inherited by the Brahmanism and Hinduism. While some groups may reject this belief, ancient Buddhism emphasizes the integral intellect as a means of salvation, which integrates magic and knowledge in the service of dharma, a law purely understandable through intellect.
